title: This Week on the Frontiers, February 10th 2018
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting frontier markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Stocks Rebound as Wild Week Ends
summary: U.S. stocks finished sharply higher Friday, thanks in part to a strong final hour, putting a positive end to one of the market’s worst weeks in years.

title: Oil Falls Further Amid Fears of Surging U.S. Output
summary: Oil prices slid below $60 a barrel, posting their biggest weekly slump in more than two years, as sharp swings in other financial markets spilled over and investors faced an onslaught of U.S. production.

title: Shares of Quintana Energy Services Trade Below Offering Price
summary: Shares of the oil-field services provider opened at $9 apiece, below a $10 offering price.

title: Copper Extends Slide on Swelling Inventories
summary: Copper prices fell for the fourth straight session, as swelling inventories pushed the base metal to its worst week since November 2014; gold dropped as the dollar’s rebound from multiyear lows weighed on the precious metal.

summary: The largest exchange-traded junk bond and bank loan funds have fallen to discounts to the value of their assets rarely seen since the products first became popular four years ago.

title: The Enlightenment Is Working
summary: Don’t listen to the gloom-sayers. The world has improved by every measure of human flourishing over the past two centuries, and the progress continues, writes Steven Pinker.

summary: Jon M. Huntsman Sr. made billions of dollars snapping up petrochemical plants that others considered losers and later used his money to fight cancer and rebuild housing in Armenia.

summary: The price of copper continued to slide amid swelling inventories and gold prices were also lower.

title: Kelner’s Take: The Public-Private Energy Venture’s Marriage of Convenience
summary: Firms seeking to deploy capital in the energy space continue to find willing partners in public oil-and-gas producers. The former’s desire to deploy a backlog of dry powder has coincided with the latter’s need for capital.

summary: Saudi Arabia is assuming supervisory control of the Saudi Binladin Group and could take a stake in the construction giant, people familiar with the matter said, a sign of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s willingness to disrupt the established corporate order in the kingdom.

title: Private-Equity Firms File to Take Oilfield-Services Providers Public
summary: Private-equity investors in the oil patch appear ready to test the public markets again as oil prices climb.

title: T. Boone Pickens Calls It Quits on Energy Trading
summary: The Oklahoma oilman and investment manager is closing the energy-focused hedge fund he has run for the past two decades after struggles with his health and returns, saying trading no longer intrigues him as it once did.

title: Deal Close Announcements: Jan. 8-12
summary: Records-storage company Iron Mountain Inc. has completed the acquisition of the U.S. operations of Sterling Partners-backed IO Data Centers LLC for about $1.34 billion. Sterling first invested in the data-center manager in 2008.

title: Riverstone Portfolio Company Soars in Public Debut
summary: Shares of private equity-backed Liberty Oilfield Services are surging in their debut.

title: Oil Rises for Fifth Straight Day as Rally Continues
summary: Oil’s rally continued to gather steam, with prices rising to fresh three-year highs as investors continued to bet on rising demand and tighter supplies.

title: China Reports Biggest-Ever Annual Trade Surplus With U.S.
summary: China reported its largest-ever annual trade surplus with the U.S. last year while its overall imbalance with the world shrank, potentially strengthening the Trump administration’s case for tougher penalties and other trade actions against Beijing.

summary: U.S. car makers are expected to see their dominance in domestic vehicle production evaporate. Sears secures new financing and Bayer nears the divestment of its Covestro holding.

summary: It’s greener than fracking and less risky than deep-water rigs.

title: Peter Sutherland Shamed Nations Into Coming Together on Trade; Later, He Called Brexit ‘Insanity’
summary: Peter Sutherland badgered and shamed 117 nations into accepting the market-opening accord that created the World Trade Organization, an engine for globalization that later helped lift China out of poverty and transformed industries world-wide.

title: French Ex-Presidents Tell Saudis of Concern About Billionaire’s Arrest
summary: Two former French presidents, François Hollande and Nicolas Sarkozy, have told Saudi Arabia’s crown prince that the arrest and detention of billionaire Prince al-Waleed bin Talal raised worries among foreign investors, according to French and Saudi government advisers.
